memberdef.argsstring: (const std::complex< double > loveNumber, const double massRatio, const double radiusRatioPowerN, const double amplitude, const std::complex< double > tideArgument, const int degree, const int order)
memberdef.name: calculateSolidBodyTideSingleCoefficientSetCorrectionFromAmplitude

detaileddescription.para: Function to calculate solid body tide gravity field variations due to single body at single degree and order from precomputed quantaties.

Function to calculate solid body tide gravity field variations due to single body at single degree and order, (frequency-independent part), after (Petit et al. 2010, eq. 6.6), using complex tidal love numbers. Using this function requires the computation of a number of precomputed quantities (as is done by the BasicSolidBodyTideGravityFieldVariations class).
loveNumber
Complex Love number for given degree and order.
massRatio
Ratio of masses of body causing deformation to body being deformed.
radiusRatioPowerN
Ratio of equatorial radius of body being deformed over distance between center of body being deformed to center of body causing deformation to the power (n+1).
amplitude
Amplitude of the tide.
tideArgument
Argument of the tide.
degree
Degree of current coefficients
order
Order of current coefficients
Combined variation in cosine (Delta C_{n,m}) and sine (Delta S_{n,m}) coefficients as: Delta C_{n,m} - i * Delta S_{n,m}
Function to calculate solid body tide gravity field variation due to single body at single degree and order.

memberdef.argsstring: (const std::complex< double > loveNumber, const double massRatio, const double referenceRadius, const Eigen::Vector3d &relativeBodyFixedPosition, const int degree, const int order)
memberdef.name: calculateSolidBodyTideSingleCoefficientSetCorrectionFromAmplitude

detaileddescription.para: Function to calculate solid body tide gravity field variations due to single body at single degree and order directly from perturbing body's Cartesian state.

Function to calculate solid body tide gravity field variations due to single body at single degree and order, (frequency-independent part), after (Petit et al. 2010, eq. 6.6), using complex tidal love numbers. This function directly uses the perturbing body's Cartesian state, and should be used for 'external' computations. The BasicSolidBodyTideGravityFieldVariations uses the alternative overloaded function.
loveNumber
Complex Love number for given degree and order.
massRatio
Ratio of masses of body causing deformation to body being deformed.
referenceRadius
Equatorial radius of body being deformed.
relativeBodyFixedPosition
Cartesian position of body causing deformation in a frame centered on and fixed to the body that is being deformed.
degree
Degree of current coefficients
order
Order of current coefficients
Combined variation in cosine (Delta C_{n,m}) and sine (Delta S_{n,m}) coefficients as: Delta C_{n,m} - i * Delta S_{n,m}
Function to calculate solid body tide gravity field variations due to single body at single degree and order directly from perturbing body's Cartesian state.

memberdef.argsstring: (const std::map< int, std::vector< std::complex< double > > > loveNumbers, const double massRatio, const double referenceRadius, const Eigen::Vector3d &relativeBodyFixedPosition, const int maximumDegree, const int maximumOrder)
memberdef.name: calculateSolidBodyTideSingleCoefficientSetCorrectionFromAmplitude

param.type: const std::map< int, std::vector< std::complex< double > > >

detaileddescription.para: Function to calculate solid body tide gravity field variations due to single body at a set of degrees and orders from perturbing body's Cartesian state.

Function to calculate solid body tide gravity field variations due to single body at a set of degrees and orders (frequency-independent part), after (Petit et al. 2010, eq. 6.6), using complex tidal love numbers. This function directly uses the perturbing body's Cartesian state, and should be used for 'external' computations. The BasicSolidBodyTideGravityFieldVariations uses the alternative overloaded function. This function defines the maximum degree and order, and always starts at degree 2 and order 0
loveNumbers
Complex Love numbers for each degree and order (index of first vector is degree-2; index of second vector is order.
massRatio
Ratio of masses of body causing deformation to body being deformed.
referenceRadius
Equatorial radius of body being deformed.
relativeBodyFixedPosition
Cartesian position of body causing deformation in a frame centered on and fixed to the body that is being deformed.
maximumDegree
Maximum degree of current coefficient corrections.
maximumOrder
Maximum order of current coefficient corrections.
Combined variation in cosine (Delta C_{n,m}) and sine (Delta S_{n,m}) matrices as first and second entry of pair, respectively. Both matrices start at degree and order 0.
Function to calculate solid body tide gravity field variations due to single body at a set of degrees and orders from perturbing body's Cartesian state.

memberdef.argsstring: (const double universalGravitationalConstant, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration, const double massOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration=Eigen::Vector3d::Zero())
memberdef.name: computeGravitationalAcceleration

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational acceleration.

detaileddescription.para:
Computes gravitational acceleration experienced by body1, due to its interaction with body2. The basis for this gravitational acceleration is that body2 is a point mass, generating acceleration due to Newton's gravitational force: \[ \bar{a}_{gravity} = -\frac{G * m_{2}}{r_{12}^{3}} * \bar{r}_{12} \] where $G$ is the universal gravitational constant, $m_{2}$ is the mass of body2, and $\bar{r}_{12}$ is the relative position vector from body1 to body 2, with respect to an inertial (barycentric) reference frame.
universalGravitationalConstant
Universal gravitational constant [m^3 kg^-1 s^-2].
positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration
Position vector of body subject to acceleration (body1) [m].
massOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Mass of body exerting acceleration (body2) [kg].
positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Position vector of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m].
Gravitational acceleration exerted on body1 [m s^-2].
computeGravitationalForce.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration, const double gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration=Eigen::Vector3d::Zero())
memberdef.name: computeGravitationalAcceleration

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational acceleration.

detaileddescription.para:
Computes gravitational acceleration experienced by body1, due to its interaction with body2. The basis for this gravitational acceleration is that body2 is a point mass, generating acceleration due to Newton's gravitational force: \[ \bar{a}_{gravity} = -\frac{\mu_{2}}{r_{12}^{3}} * \bar{r}_{12} \] where $\mu_{2}$ is the gravitational parameter of the body exerting acceleration, and $\bar{r}_{12}$ is the relative position vector from body1 to body 2, with respect to an inertial (barycentric) reference frame.
positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration
Position vector of body subject to acceleration (body1) [m].
gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Gravitational parameter of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m^3 s^-2].
positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Position vector of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m].
Gravitational acceleration exerted on body1 [m s^-2].
computeGravitationalForce.

memberdef.argsstring: (const double universalGravitationalParameter, const double massOfBodySubjectToForce, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToForce, const double massOfBodyExertingForce, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodyExertingForce=Eigen::Vector3d::Zero())
memberdef.name: computeGravitationalForce

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational force.

detaileddescription.para:
Computes gravitational force experienced by body1, due to its interaction with body2. The basis for this gravitational force is that both body1 and body2 are point masses, generating Newton's gravitational force: \[ \bar{F}_{gravity} = -\frac{G * m_{1} * m_{2}}{r_{12}^{3}} * \bar{r}_{12} \] where $G$ is the universal gravitational constant, $m_{1}$ is the mass of body1, $m_{2}$ is the mass of body2, and $\bar{r}_{12}$ is the relative position vector from body1 to body 2, with respect to an inertial (barycentric) reference frame.
universalGravitationalParameter
Universal gravitational constant [m^3 kg^-1 s^-2].
massOfBodySubjectToForce
Mass of body subject to force (body1) [kg].
positionOfBodySubjectToForce
Position vector of body subject to force (body1) [m].
massOfBodyExertingForce
Mass of body exerting force (body2) [kg].
positionOfBodyExertingForce
Position vector of body exerting force (body2) [m].
Gravitational force exerted on body1 [N].
computeGravitationalAcceleration.

memberdef.argsstring: (const double massOfBodySubjectToForce, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToForce, const double gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingForce, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodyExertingForce=Eigen::Vector3d::Zero())
memberdef.name: computeGravitationalForce

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational force.

detaileddescription.para:
Computes gravitational force experienced by body1, due to its interaction with another body (body2) The basis for this gravitational force is that both body1 and body2 are point masses, generating Newton's gravitational force: \[ \bar{F}_{gravity} = -\frac{m_{1} * \mu_{2}}{r_{12}^{3}} * \bar{r}_{12} \] where $m_{1}$ is the mass of body1, $\mu_{2}$ is the gravitational parameter of the central body (body2), and $\bar{r}_{12}$ is the relative position vector from body1 to the body exerting the force (body2), with respect to an inertial (barycentric) reference frame.
massOfBodySubjectToForce
Mass of body subject to force (body1) [kg].
positionOfBodySubjectToForce
Position vector of body subject to force (body1) [m].
gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingForce
Gravitational parameter of body exerting force (body2) [m^3 s^-2].
positionOfBodyExertingForce
Position vector of body exerting force (body2) [m].
Gravitational force exerted on body1 [N].
computeGravitationalAcceleration.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration, const double gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const double equatorialRadiusOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const double j2CoefficientOfGravityField, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration)
memberdef.name: computeGravitationalAccelerationDueToJ2

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational acceleration due to J2.

detaileddescription.para:
Computes gravitational acceleration experienced by body1, due to its interaction with another body (body2) with an irregular gravity field. The body exerting the acceleration has an irregular gravity field. The acceleration due to the J2-coefficient is given by (Melman, 2012): \begin{eqnarray*} {a}_{gravity,x} &=& -\mu_{2}*\frac{x_{1}-x_{2}}{r^{3}} * \frac{3}{2}*J_{2} * \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{2} * (1-5*\hat{z}^2) \\ {a}_{gravity,y} &=& -\mu_{2}*\frac{y_{1}-y_{2}}{r^{3}} * \frac{3}{2}*J_{2} * \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{2} * (1-5*\hat{z}^2) \\ {a}_{gravity,z} &=& \frac{-\mu_{2}}{r^{2}} * \frac{3}{2}*J_{2} * \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{2} * (3-5*\hat{z}^2) * \hat{z} \\ \end{eqnarray*} where $\mu_{2}$ is the gravitational parameter of the body exerting acceleration, $\hat{z} = \frac{z}{r}$, $x$, $y$ and $z$ are the Cartesian position components, $r$ is the radial position, and $J_{2}$ is the second zonal coefficient of the gravity field of body2. The positions and accelerations are given with respect to an inertial (barycentric) reference frame.
positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration
Position vector of body subject to J2-acceleration (body1) [m].
gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Gravitational parameter of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m^3 s^-2].
equatorialRadiusOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Equatorial radius of body exerting acceleration (body2), in formulation of spherical harmonics expansion [m].
j2CoefficientOfGravityField
J2-coefficient, describing irregularity of the gravity field of body2 [-].
positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Position vector of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m].
Gravitational acceleration exerted on body1 due to J2-effect [m s^-2].

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration, const double gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const double equatorialRadiusOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const double j3CoefficientOfGravityField, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration)
memberdef.name: computeGravitationalAccelerationDueToJ3

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational acceleration due to J3.

detaileddescription.para:
Computes gravitational acceleration experienced by body1, due to its interaction with another body (body2) with an irregular gravity field. The body exerting the acceleration has an irregular gravity field. The acceleration due to the J3-coefficient is given by (Melman, 2012): \begin{eqnarray*} {a}_{gravity,x} &=& -\mu_{2}*\frac{x_{1}-x_{2}}{r^{3}} * \frac{5}{2}*J_{3} * \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{3} * (3-7*\hat{z}^2) * \hat{z} \\ {a}_{gravity,y} &=& -\mu_{2}*\frac{y_{1}-y_{2}}{r^{3}} * \frac{5}{2}*J_{3} * \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{3} * (3-7*\hat{z}^2) * \hat{z} \\ {a}_{gravity,z} &=& \frac{-\mu_{2}}{r^{2}} * \frac{5}{2}*J_{3} * \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{3} * (-\frac{3}{5}+6*\hat{z}^2-7*\hat{z}^4) \\ \end{eqnarray*} where $\mu_{2}$ is the gravitational parameter of the body exerting acceleration, $\hat{z} = \frac{z}{r}$, $x$, $y$ and $z$ are the Cartesian position components, $r$ is the radial position, and $J_{3}$ is the third zonal coefficient of the gravity field of body2. The positions and accelerations are given with respect to an inertial (barycentric) reference frame.
positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration
Position vector of body subject to J3-acceleration (body1) [m].
gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Gravitational parameter of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m^3 s^-2].
equatorialRadiusOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Equatorial radius of body exerting acceleration (body2), in formulation of spherical harmonics expansion [m].
j3CoefficientOfGravityField
J3-coefficient, describing irregularity of the gravity field of body2 [-].
positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Position vector of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m].
Gravitational acceleration exerted on body1 due to J3-effect [m s^-2].

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration, const double gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const double equatorialRadiusOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const double j4CoefficientOfGravityField, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration)
memberdef.name: computeGravitationalAccelerationDueToJ4

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational acceleration due to J4.

detaileddescription.para:
Computes gravitational acceleration experienced by body1, due to its interaction with another body (body2) with an irregular gravity field. The body exerting the acceleration has an irregular gravity field. The acceleration due to the J4-coefficient is given by (Melman, 2012): \begin{eqnarray*} {a}_{gravity,x} &=& \mu_{2}*\frac{x_{1}-x_{2}}{r^{3}} * \frac{35}{8}*J_{4} * \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{4} * (\frac{3}{7}-6*\hat{z}^2+9*\hat{z}^{4}) \\ {a}_{gravity,y} &=& \mu_{2}*\frac{y_{1}-y_{2}}{r^{3}} * \frac{35}{8}*J_{4} * \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{4} * (\frac{3}{7}-6*\hat{z}^2+9*\hat{z}^{4}) \\ {a}_{gravity,z} &=& \frac{\mu_{2}}{r^{2}} * \frac{35}{8}*J_{4} * \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{4} * (\frac{15}{7}-10*\hat{z}^2+9*\hat{z}^4) * \hat{z} \\ \end{eqnarray*} where $\mu_{2}$ is the gravitational parameter of the body exerting acceleration, $\hat{z} = \frac{z}{r}$, $x$, $y$ and $z$ are the Cartesian position components, $r$ is the radial position, and $J_{4}$ is the fourth zonal coefficient of the gravity field of body2. The positions and accelerations are given with respect to an inertial (barycentric) reference frame.
positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration
Position vector of body subject to J4-acceleration (body1) [m].
gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Gravitational parameter of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m^3 s^-2].
equatorialRadiusOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Equatorial radius of body exerting acceleration (body2), in formulation of spherical harmonics expansion [m].
j4CoefficientOfGravityField
J4-coefficient, describing irregularity of the gravity field of body2 [-].
positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Position vector of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m].
Gravitational acceleration exerted on body1 due to J4-effect [m s^-2].

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration, const double gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const double equatorialRadiusOfBodyExertingAcceleration, const std::map< int, double > zonalCoefficientsOfGravityField, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration)
memberdef.name: computeGravitationalAccelerationZonalSum

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational acceleration zonal sum.

detaileddescription.para:
Computes sum of gravitational acceleration for given zonal terms experienced by body1, due to its interaction with another body (body2) with an irregular gravity field. The body exerting the acceleration has an irregular gravity field. This function essentially serves as a wrapper to compute the total gravitational acceleration up to a certain zonal terms (specified as input parameter). So given $n$ as the maximum order of the zonal terms, the total acceleration is computed as: \begin{eqnarray*} {a}_{gravity sum,x} &=& {a}_{gravity central,x} + \sum\limits_{i=2}^{n} {a}_{gravity J_{n},x} \\ {a}_{gravity sum,y} &=& {a}_{gravity central,y} + \sum\limits_{i=2}^{n} {a}_{gravity J_{n},y} \\ {a}_{gravity sum,z} &=& {a}_{gravity central,z} + \sum\limits_{i=2}^{n} {a}_{gravity J_{n},z} \\ \end{eqnarray*} where $J_{n}$ is the coefficient describing the irregularity of the gravity field of body2 due to the nth zonal term. All accelerations are given with respect to an inertial (barycentric) reference frame. NOTE: Currently, this algorithm only computes accelerations up to $J_{4}$.
positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration
Position vector of body subject to J4-acceleration (body1) [m].
gravitationalParameterOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Gravitational parameter of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m^3 s^-2].
equatorialRadiusOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Equatorial radius of body exerting acceleration (body2), in formulation of spherical harmonics expansion [m].
zonalCoefficientsOfGravityField
Coefficients of zonal terms, describing irregularity of the gravity field of body2 [-]. The map key contains the degree, and the map value contains the coefficient value. At the moment, the only degrees supported are 2 ( $J_{2}$), 3 ( $J_{3}$), and 4 ( $J_{4}$) etc. An error is thrown for any other values.
positionOfBodyExertingAcceleration
Position vector of body exerting acceleration (body2) [m].
Total gravitational acceleration exerted on body1 due to given zonal terms [m s^-2].

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector6d relativeStateOfBodyExertingTide, const Eigen::Vector3d planetAngularVelocityVector, const double currentTidalAccelerationMultiplier, const double timeLag, const bool includeDirectRadialComponent=true)
memberdef.name: computeDirectTidalAccelerationDueToTideOnPlanet

briefdescription.para: Function to compute the acceleration acting on a satellite due to tidal deformation caused by this satellite on host planet.

detaileddescription.para:
Function to compute the acceleration acting on a satellite due to tidal deformation caused by this satellite on host planet. The computation is according to Lainey et al. (2007, 2009, 2012, etc.) and uses a single (degree 2) real Love number and a single time lag to include the dissipation in the host planet.
relativeStateOfBodyExertingTide
State of satellite w.r.t. host planet.
planetAngularVelocityVector
Angular velocity vector ogf host planet
currentTidalAccelerationMultiplier
Scalar multiplier that is common to all vector terms (term outside of brackets in Eq. (3) of Lainey et al. (2007)).
timeLag
Time lag of tidal bulge
includeDirectRadialComponent
True if term independent of time lag is to be included, false otherwise
Value of acceleration vector according to tidal model

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector6d relativeStateOfBodyExertingTide, const double currentTidalAccelerationMultiplier, const double timeLag, const bool includeDirectRadialComponent)
memberdef.name: computeDirectTidalAccelerationDueToTideOnSatellite

briefdescription.para: Function to compute the acceleration acting on a satellite due to tidal deformation caused in this satellite by host planet.

detaileddescription.para:
Function to compute the acceleration acting on a satellite due to tidal deformation caused in this satellite by host planet. The computation is according to Lainey et al. (2007, 2009, 2012, etc.) and uses a single (degree 2) real Love number and a single time lag to include the dissipation in the host planet.
relativeStateOfBodyExertingTide
State of satellite w.r.t. host planet.
currentTidalAccelerationMultiplier
Scalar multiplier that is common to all vector terms (term outside of brackets in Eq. (3) of Lainey et al. (2007), modified according to tide on satellite).
timeLag
Time lag of tidal bulge
includeDirectRadialComponent
True if term independent of time lag is to be included, false otherwise
Value of acceleration vector according to tidal model

memberdef.name: createInterpolatedSphericalHarmonicCorrectionFunctions

detaileddescription.para: Function to create a function linearly interpolating the sine and cosine correction coefficients produced by an object of GravityFieldVariations type.

Function to create a function linearly interpolating the sine and cosine correction coefficients produced by an object of GravityFieldVariations type. The function creates a function pointer to the getCosineSinePair function of PairInterpolationInterface. The object of type PairInterpolationInterface is created by generating an interpolator for sine/cosine coefficients from the variationObject object and the initial/final time and time step that are passed.
variationObject
Object generating cosine and sine coefficient corrections.
initialTime
Start time of interpolator.
finalTime
End time of interpolator.
timeStep
Time step between subsequent evaluations of coefficient corrections
Function pointer to function mimicing the addSphericalHarmonicsCorrections function of GravityFieldVariations.
Function to create a function linearly interpolating the sine and cosine correction coefficients produced by an object of GravityFieldVariations type.

memberdef.argsstring: (const double massParameter, const Eigen::VectorXd &stateInNormalizedUnits)
memberdef.name: computeJacobiEnergy

briefdescription.para: Compute Jacobi energy.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the value of the Jacobi energy in normalized units of the CRTBP, given in the following equation (Wakker, 2007): \[ C_{J} = x^{2} + y^{2} + 2 * \left(\frac{1-\mu}{r_{1}} + \frac{\mu}{r_{2}}\right) - V^{2}, \] where $C_{J}$ is the Jacobi energy, $x$ and $y$ are Cartesian position coordinates of the third body, $mu$ is the gravitational parameter of the secondary, $r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ are the distances from the third body to the primaries, and $V$ is the magnitude of the velocity of the third body. This equation assumes that the system has been normalized such that the mean motion of the primiaries, and their mutual distance is equal to 1.
massParameter
Mass parameter of three-body system.
stateInNormalizedUnits
State of third body in normalized units.
Jacobi energy in normalized units.

memberdef.argsstring: (const std::function< Eigen::MatrixXd() > originalCosineCoefficientFunction)
memberdef.name: setDegreeAndOrderCoefficientToZero

briefdescription.para: Function to manually remove the C(0,0) term from cosine coefficients,.

detaileddescription.para: Function to manually remove the C(0,0) term from cosine coefficients.

Function to manually remove the C(0,0) term from cosine coefficients, used by MutualSphericalHarmonicsGravitationalAccelerationModel. By using this function, the original function returning the sh coefficients is left untouched, not compromising the environment model, while the C(0,0) term is not calculated doubly by the MutualSphericalHarmonicsGravitationalAccelerationModel class.

detaileddescription.para:
Function to calculate the gravitational torque exerted by a point mass on a body with degree two gravity field, which is provided here as an inertia tensor. Higher order terms of the torque are omitted.
relativePositionOfBodySubjectToTorque
Position of body exerting torque, w.r.t. body undergoing torque (typically expressed in frame fixed to body undergoing torque).
premultipler
Torque pre-multipler (3*mu/r^5).
inertiaTensorTimesRelativePositionOfBody
The inertia tensor of the body undergoing the torque, multiplied by relativePositionOfBodySubjectToTorque
Gravitational torque of point mass on second-degree body.

memberdef.name: calculateSphericalHarmonicGravitationalPotential

briefdescription.para: Function to calculate the gravitational potential from a spherical harmonic field expansion.

detaileddescription.para:
Function to calculate the gravitational potential from a spherical harmonic field expansion.
bodyFixedPosition
Position of point at which potential is to be calculated wrt the massive body, in the frame in which the expansion is defined (typically body-fixed).
gravitationalParameter
Gravitational parameter of massive body.
referenceRadius
Reference radius of spherical harmonic field expansion.
cosineCoefficients
Cosine spherical harmonic coefficients (geodesy normalized).
sineCoefficients
Sine spherical harmonic coefficients (geodesy normalized).
sphericalHarmonicsCache
Cache object containing current values of trigonometric funtions of latitude anf longitude, as well as legendre polynomials at current state.
minimumumDegree
Maximum degree of spherical harmonic expansion.
minimumumOrder
Maximum order of spherical harmonic expansion.
Gravitational potential at position defined by bodyFixedPosition

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration, const double gravitationalParameter, const double equatorialRadius, const Eigen::MatrixXd &cosineHarmonicCoefficients, const Eigen::MatrixXd &sineHarmonicCoefficients, std::shared_ptr< basic_mathematics::SphericalHarmonicsCache > sphericalHarmonicsCache, std::map< std::pair< int, int >, Eigen::Vector3d > &accelerationPerTerm, const bool saveSeparateTerms, const Eigen::Matrix3d &accelerationRotation)
memberdef.name: computeGeodesyNormalizedGravitationalAccelerationSum

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational acceleration due to multiple spherical harmonics terms, defined using geodesy-normalization.

detaileddescription.para: Compute gravitational acceleration due to multiple spherical harmonics terms, defined using geodesy-normalization.

This function computes the acceleration caused by gravitational spherical harmonics, with the coefficients expressed using a geodesy-normalization. This acceleration is the summation of all harmonic terms from degree and order zero, up to a user-specified highest degree and order. The harmonic coefficients for the function must be provided in geodesy-normalized format. This geodesy-normalization is defined as: \begin{eqnarray*} \bar{ C }_{ n, m } = \Pi_{ n, m } C_{ n, m } \\ \bar{ S }_{ n, m } = \Pi_{ n, m } S_{ n, m } \end{eqnarray*} in which $ \bar{ C }_{ n, m } $ and $ \bar{ S }_{ n, m } $ are a geodesy-normalized cosine and sine harmonic coefficient respectively (of degree $ n $ and order $ m $). The unnormalized harmonic coefficients are represented by $ C_{ n, m } $ and $ S_{ n, m } $. The normalization factor $ \Pi_{ n, m } $ is given by Heiskanen & Moritz [1967] as: \[ \Pi_{ n, m } = \sqrt{ \frac{ ( n + m )! }{ ( 2 - \delta_{ 0, m } ) ( 2 n + 1 ) ( n - m )! } } \] in which $ n $ is the degree, $ m $ is the order and $ \delta_{ 0, m } $ is the Kronecker delta.
positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration
Cartesian position vector with respect to the reference frame that is associated with the harmonic coefficients. The order is important! position( 0 ) = x coordinate [m], position( 1 ) = y coordinate [m], position( 2 ) = z coordinate [m].
gravitationalParameter
Gravitational parameter associated with the spherical harmonics [m^3 s^-2].
equatorialRadius
Reference radius of the spherical harmonics [m].
cosineHarmonicCoefficients
Matrix with geodesy-normalized cosine harmonic coefficients. The row index indicates the degree and the column index indicates the order of coefficients.
sineHarmonicCoefficients
Matrix with geodesy-normalized sine harmonic coefficients. The row index indicates the degree and the column index indicates the order of coefficients. The matrix must be equal in size to cosineHarmonicCoefficients.
sphericalHarmonicsCache
Cache object for computing/retrieving repeated terms in spherical harmonics potential gradient calculation.
accelerationPerTerm
List of contributions to accelerations at given degrees/orders, represented by first/second entry of map key pair. List is returned by reference only if saveSeparateTerms is set to true.
saveSeparateTerms
Boolean to denote whether the separate terms in the acceleration are to be stored term by term (in accelerationPerTerm map) by reference
accelerationRotation
Rotation from body-fixed frame (in which coefficients are defined) to inertial frame.
Cartesian acceleration vector resulting from the summation of all harmonic terms. The order is important! acceleration( 0 ) = x acceleration [m s^-2], acceleration( 1 ) = y acceleration [m s^-2], acceleration( 2 ) = z acceleration [m s^-2].

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration, const double gravitationalParameter, const double equatorialRadius, const int degree, const int order, const double cosineHarmonicCoefficient, const double sineHarmonicCoefficient, std::shared_ptr< basic_mathematics::SphericalHarmonicsCache > sphericalHarmonicsCache)
memberdef.name: computeSingleGeodesyNormalizedGravitationalAcceleration

briefdescription.para: Compute gravitational acceleration due to single spherical harmonics term.

detaileddescription.para:
This function computes the acceleration caused by a single gravitational spherical harmonics term, with the coefficients expressed using a geodesy-normalization. The harmonic coefficients for the function must be provided in geodesy-normalized format. This geodesy-normalization is defined as: \begin{eqnarray*} \bar{ C }_{ n, m } = \Pi_{ n, m } C_{ n, m } \\ \bar{ S }_{ n, m } = \Pi_{ n, m } S_{ n, m } \end{eqnarray*} in which $ \bar{ C }_{ n, m } $ and $ \bar{ S }_{ n, m } $ are a geodesy-normalized cosine and sine harmonic coefficient respectively (of degree $ n $ and order $ m $). The unnormalized harmonic coefficients are represented by $ C_{ n, m } $ and $ S_{ n, m } $. The normalization factor $ \Pi_{ n, m } $ is given by Heiskanen & Moritz [1967] as: \[ \Pi_{ n, m } = \sqrt{ \frac{ ( n + m )! }{ ( 2 - \delta_{ 0, m } ) ( 2 n + 1 ) ( n - m )! } } \] in which $ n $ is the degree, $ m $ is the order and $ \delta_{ 0, m } $ is the Kronecker delta.
positionOfBodySubjectToAcceleration
Cartesian position vector with respect to the reference frame that is associated with the harmonic coefficients. The order is important! position( 0 ) = x coordinate [m], position( 1 ) = y coordinate [m], position( 2 ) = z coordinate [m].
degree
Degree of the harmonic term.
order
Order of the harmonic term.
cosineHarmonicCoefficient
Geodesy-normalized cosine harmonic coefficient.
sineHarmonicCoefficient
Geodesy-normalized sine harmonic coefficient.
gravitationalParameter
Gravitational parameter associated with the spherical harmonic [m^3 s^-2].
equatorialRadius
Reference radius of the spherical harmonic [m].
sphericalHarmonicsCache
Cache object for computing/retrieving repeated terms in spherical harmonics potential gradient calculation.
Cartesian acceleration vector resulting from the spherical harmonic term. The order is important! acceleration( 0 ) = x acceleration [m s^-2], acceleration( 1 ) = y acceleration [m s^-2], acceleration( 2 ) = z acceleration [m s^-2].

memberdef.argsstring: (const double gravitationalParameterOfPerturbingBody, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfPerturbingBody, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfAffectedBody, const Eigen::Vector3d &positionOfCentralBody=Eigen::Vector3d::Zero())
memberdef.name: computeThirdBodyPerturbingAcceleration

briefdescription.para: Compute perturbing acceleration by third body.

detaileddescription.para:
Computes the perturbing acceleration on a point mass in orbit about a central body (point mass), caused by a third body (point mass). This acceleration is expressed with respect to a pseudo-inertial reference frame centered at the central body body, i.e, a non-rotating frame aligned with an inertial reference frame. This acceleration may be summed with other third body accelerations in order to get the total gravitational perturbation acceleration of N bodies (Wakker, 2010; Montenbruck & Gill, 2005).
gravitationalParameterOfPerturbingBody
The gravitational parameter of the perturbing body, i.e., the third body. [m^3/s^2]
positionOfPerturbingBody
The position of the third body, the body that causes the perturbations, in Cartesian coordinates. positionOfPerturbingBody( 0 ) = x-position [m] positionOfPerturbingBody( 1 ) = y-position [m] positionOfPerturbingBody( 2 ) = z-position [m]
positionOfAffectedBody
The position of the second body, the body that experiences the perturbation, in Cartesian coordinates. positionOfAffectedBody( 0 ) = x-position [m] positionOfAffectedBody( 1 ) = y-position [m] positionOfAffectedBody( 2 ) = z-position [m]
positionOfCentralBody
The position of the central body, the body w.r.t. which the acceleration is calculated the perturbation, in Cartesian coordinates (default=origin). positionOfAffectedBody( 0 ) = x-position [m] positionOfAffectedBody( 1 ) = y-position [m] positionOfAffectedBody( 2 ) = z-position [m]
perturbingAcceleration The perturbing acceleration in Cartesian components, that gives the difference of the total acceleration with the central two-body acceleration. perturbingAcceleration( 0 ) = x-acceleration [m/s^2] perturbingAcceleration( 1 ) = y-acceleration [m/s^2] perturbingAcceleration( 2 ) = z-acceleration [m/s^2]

memberdef.argsstring: (const double aSquaredMinusCSquared, const double bSquaredMinusCSquared, const double referenceRadius, const int degree, const int order)
memberdef.name: calculateCosineTermForTriaxialEllipsoidSphericalHarmonicGravity

detaileddescription.para: Function to calculate (non-normalized) cosine spherical harmonic coefficient for a homogeneous triaxial ellipsoid

Function to calculate (non-normalized) cosine spherical harmonic coefficient for a homogeneous triaxial ellipsoid, from method of Boyce (1997) at a given degree and order. X-axis is alligned with largest axis, y-axis with middle axis and z-axis with smallest axis
aSquaredMinusCSquared
Square of largest axis minus square of shortest axis
bSquaredMinusCSquared
Square of middle axis minus square of shortest axis
referenceRadius
Reference radius of spherical harmonic gravity field.
degree
Degree of coefficient
order
Order of coefficient
Spherical harmonic cosine coefficient (non-normalized) of triaxial ellipsoid at requested degree and order.
Function to calculate (non-normalized) cosine spherical harmonic coefficient for a homogeneous triaxial ellipsoid

memberdef.name: createTriAxialEllipsoidSphericalHarmonicCoefficients

detaileddescription.para: Function to calculate (non-normalized) cosine and sine spherical harmonic coefficients for a homogeneous triaxial ellipsoid

Function to calculate (non-normalized) cosine and sinespherical harmonic coefficients for a homogeneous triaxial ellipsoid, from method of Boyce (1997) up to given degree and order. X-axis is alligned with largest axis, y-axis with middle axis and z-axis with smallest axis. Note that all sine coefficients are zero for all homogeneous triaxila ellipsoids (in given frame).
axisA
Largest axis of triaxial ellipsoid
axisB
Middle axis of triaxial ellipsoid
axisC
Smallest axis of triaxial ellipsoid
maximumDegree
Maximum degree of expansion
maximumOrder
Maximum oredr of expansion
Spherical harmonic cosine and coefficient matrix (non-normalized) pair of triaxial ellipsoid up to requested degree and order.
Function to calculate (non-normalized) cosine and sine spherical harmonic coefficients for a homogeneous triaxial ellipsoid
